The Cistercian rule, at least in ScotlamL had remittod much of its ascetic rigour before Ferrerius came among our countrymen. Painting and the ornamental arts, which were originally discouraged by the Bor- nardine institutes, yet owed much to the patronage of those wealthy establishments in a country hitherto too poor, and too disturbed for their general encouragement. The famous painter(¹) of the Abbey of Kinloss and his works, it is feared, are alike unknown to fame; but it is easy to conceive what influence a foreign artist, even of secondary merit, might have in forming that excellent native school which so soon arose in Scot- land.
